questions.text: While assessing a newborn for maturity, which of the following findings does not suggest prematurity?
questions.solution: Commonly assessed components for checking the maturity are:

choices.text: 30 w to 31 w 6 d GA (gestational age)
32 w to 33 w 6 d GA
34 w to 36 w 6 d GA
37 w to 37 w 6 d GA

questions.text: By definition, what is called as late preterm baby?
questions.solution:
Preterm are born at <37 completed weeks of gestation (258 days). Subgroups of preterm infant include the following:

  • Extremely preterm infants are born <28 weeks (195 days).
  • Early preterm infants are born <34 weeks (237 days).
  • Late preterm infants are born between 34 0/7 and 36 6/7 weeks of gestation (238 to 258 days).
  • Term infants are born between 37 0/7 and 41 6/7 weeks of gestation (259 to 293 days).
  • Early term infants are subgroup of term infants born between 37 0/7 and 38 6/7 weeks of gestation (259 to 272 days).
  • Post term infants are born after 42 weeks of gestation (294 days) or more.

questions.text: A baby is born at 43 w 4 d of gestational age. Which of the following morbidity is not to be anticipated in this baby?
questions.solution:
Morbidities associated with post-term pregnancy include the presence of

  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid (option a)
  • Meconium aspiration
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing in labor
  • Low apgar scores,
  • Birth injury (option c)
  • Fetal macrosomia (option d)
  • Fetal weight loss

questions.text: In a monochorionic monoamniotic twin with uncompensated arteriovenous shunt, which of the following characteristic is present in donor twin that helps differentiating it from the recipient twin?
questions.solution: Monochorionic twin with uncompensated arteriovenous shunt has following differentiating features:

choices.text: Swelling of the soft tissue of scalp
Does not cross the suture lines

questions.text: A newborn comes to you on 2nd day of life with following finding. The child was delivered by normal vaginal delivery with forceps assistance. Which of the following finding feature is not expected to be present in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The child in the image has It is a subperiosteal hemorrhage.
  • The closest differential diagnosis is caput succedaneum. It is the swelling of the soft tissues of scalp.

questions.text: A full-term newborn has history of delayed cry and suspected hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy. The baby is hyperalert with exaggerated tendon reflexes, clonus and a normal EEG. What is the stage of HIE?
questions.solution: Important points from SARNAT and SARNAT staging for HIE

choices.text: Auscultation of breath sounds equally on both chest sides

questions.text: A neonate is on ventilatory support due to respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following marker does not indicate successful ventilation in the child?
questions.solution:
End Tidal CO2 indicates the concentration of exhaled CO2. It must not be zero. Increased EtCO2 indicates retention of CO2, while reduced EtCO2 indicates hyperventilation.

Markers for good ventilation are:

  • Bilateral equal chest rise (option a)
  • Bilateral symmetrical breath sounds (option b)
  • Heart rate stable and >100/min (option c)
  • Spontaneous breathing
  • Pink color of skin
  • Presence of EtCO2 reading

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation, while giving chest compression what should be the ratio of chest compression to bag and mask ventilation rate to be maintained?
questions.solution:
• The chest compression to breathing ratio must be maintained as 3:1 in newborns.
  • It is 15:2 in children for two rescuers and 30:2 in children with single rescuer.
  • 30:2 in adults.

Reference: AAP Basic Life Support Guidelines 2015 and Neonatal Resuscitation Guidelines 2021

choices.text: Endotracheal intubation and chest compression and Intratracheal adrenaline

questions.text: A 38 week term baby is delivered by emergency cesarean section due to non reassuring doppler findings. The baby did not cry after birth. At birth, there was no spontaneous breathing on stimulation, HR<100 palpated in umbilical artery, center and periphery were blue and baby was limp. After bag and mask ventilation for 30s, there was no spontaneous breathing and HR<60. Which of the following is the next step?
questions.solution: Reference: AAP Basic Life Support Guidelines 2015 and Neonatal Resuscitation Guidelines 2021

questions.text: What is the proper dose of adrenaline to be used during neonatal resuscitation if given endotracheally?
questions.solution:
• Adrenaline must be administered by IV route at 0.01-0.03mg/kg if venous access is available.
  • If IV access is difficult, endotracheally administer adrenaline at 0.05-0.1mg/kg.

questions.text: What is the current IAP recommendation for Vitamin D3 supplementation in a full-term neonate?
questions.solution:
• All infants younger than 12 months should receive 400 IU daily beginning within the first few days after birth.
  • Healthy children 1 to 18 years of age should receive 600 IU daily.
  • Children with liver disease, kidney disease, or malabsorption (i.e., secondary to cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease [IBD], etc.) as well as premature infants need even higher doses to account for the limitations in vitamin D metabolism or absorption brought on by these health issues.

Reference: IAP guidelines for prevention and treatment of Rickets, 2017

questions.text: A 4kg post term baby is delivered at 43weeks of gestation with difficult vaginal delivery. Forceps assistance was needed while delivering the baby. On 15th day mother comes to you with complaint that child moves the right hand significantly less since birth compared to left. Child is otherwise fine, feeding well and gaining weight. What pathology you suspect in this child for the condition?
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has Erb's palsy.
  • Cause: excessive traction on the head, neck and arm during birth.
  • Risk factors: macrosomia, shoulder dystocia, malpresentation and instrumental deliveries. (in our case, macrosomia and instrumental delivery were present)
  • Duchenne-Erb palsy involves the upper trunks (C5, C6, and occasionally C7) and is the most common type of brachial plexus injury, accounting for approximately 90% of cases.
  • The arm is typically adducted and internally rotated at the shoulder. There is extension and pronation at the elbow and flexion of the wrist and fingers in the characteristic 'waiter's tip' posture.
  • The deltoid, infraspinatus, biceps, supinator, and brachioradialis muscles, and the extensors of the wrist and fingers may be weak or paralyzed.
  • The Moro, biceps, and radial reflexes are absent on the affected side. The grasp reflex is intact.
  • Sensation is variably affected.
  • Diaphragm paralysis occurs in 5% of cases.
  • Option C: Klumpke's palsy, involves C8-T1 with typical Claw hand deformity. Instrumental delivery is a risk factor. It is rarest of the trauma in newborn.
  • Option B: Humerus fracture will be painful and will not show waiter's tip deformity as seen in the image.
  • Option D: Pulled elbow is extended and forearm is pronated. It is generally caused after jerky lifting of the baby and not since birth. It is extremely painful.

choices.text: Broad nasal bridge, cleft palate, microcephaly
Short palpebral fissures, midface hypoplasia, smooth philtrum, thin superior vermillion border

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities are consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome?
questions.solution:
Characteristics of fetal alcohol syndrome include

  • Prenatal onset and persistence of growth deficiency for length, weight, and head circumference
  • Facial abnormalities- including short palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, maxillary hypoplasia, micrognathia, smooth philtrum, and a thin, smooth upper lip.

  • Cardiac defects- primarily septal defects
  • Minor joint and limb abnormalities- some restriction of movement and altered palmar crease patterns
  • Delay of development and mental deficiency varying from borderline to severe.

questions.text: A 38 week, 3.2kg baby boy is born by spontaneous vaginal delivery. At 5 minutes he has a heart rate over 100, is crying with grimace, is pink all over and continues to move all limbs equally. What is his Apgar score at 5 minutes?

A mother is very reluctant in giving breast feeding to her newborn. She is lactating well. But she has a fear that her milk is not good for her baby. While counselling the mother about the advantages of breast milk, she must be explained that breast milk protects against multiple types of infections. Which of the following infection is not prevented in exclusively breastfed child?
questions.solution:
• Breastfeeding has been suggested to have a possible protective effect in :
    • Diarrhea
    • Otitis media (option a)
    • Urinary tract infections (option b)
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis,
    • Septicemia (option c)
    • Infant botulism
    • Celiac disease
    • Childhood cancer
    • Allergy
    • Hospitalizations and infant mortality
